citations.narrative:
While reviewing disposition and inventory records, it was revealed that an adult male Ringed teal (ID number: 10521)
disappeared from its enclosure in the Waterfowl Exhibit at some point on Sunday, February 16, 2025. According to the
keeper, during the morning headcount of the birds in this exhibit on Monday, February 17, 2025, they realized the teal
was missing. The keeper was unsure if they counted the bird during their evening check the day before. Although there
was no evidence of predation, and the bird was pinioned, the facility staff continued their search for the bird for several
days thereafter, but recovery was unfortunately unsuccessful. While the facility remains uncertain as to how the bird
disappeared, it is believed that it was possibly stolen by a member of the public. Inadequate construction/maintenance of
primary enclosures offers the opportunity for the well-being of the birds contained therein to be negatively impacted in
various ways (i.e., predation, escape, etc.). Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they contain
the birds securely. The facility applied the following corrective actions: Performance counseling was completed with the
keeper that was directly involved with the incident; replacement of the roofs on all bird enclosures and additional
construction changes to increase security; review of proper policies/procedures with all keepers; and lastly, the facility is
in the process of installing cameras throughout the zoo grounds.
Correct by: Corrected prior to inspection
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12JUL2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.153(a)(1)(iii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
While reviewing disposition and inventory records, it was revealed that an adult male Ringed teal (ID number: 10521) 
disappeared from its enclosure in the Waterfowl Exhibit at some point on Sunday, February 16, 2025. According to the 
keeper, during the morning headcount of the birds in this exhibit on Monday, February 17, 2025, they realized the teal 
was missing. The keeper was unsure if they counted the bird during their evening check the day before. Although there 
was no evidence of predation, and the bird was pinioned, the facility staff continued their search for the bird for several 
days thereafter, but recovery was unfortunately unsuccessful. While the facility remains uncertain as to how the bird 
disappeared, it is believed that it was possibly stolen by a member of the public. Inadequate construction/maintenance of 
primary enclosures offers the opportunity for the well-being of the birds contained therein to be negatively impacted in 
various ways (i.e., predation, escape, etc.). Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they contain 
the birds securely. The facility applied the following corrective actions: Performance counseling was completed with the 
keeper that was directly involved with the incident; replacement of the roofs on all bird enclosures and additional 
construction changes to increase security; review of proper policies/procedures with all keepers; and lastly, the facility is 
in the process of installing cameras throughout the zoo grounds.  
 
Correct by: Corrected prior to inspection 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12JUL2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.common: JAMAICAN FRUIT-EATING BAT / JAMAICAN FRUIT BAT
